## Collective behaviour theory (CBT)

- origins: something went wrong in the interwar years -- what precisely and [why]{style="color:red;"}?
    * mix of sociological and psychological approach---influenced by scholarship of Durkheim and Marx
- some key scholars: Ted Gurr, Ralph Turner and Lewis Killian

- movements as part of 'emergent phenomena,' ranging from trends and gossip, to collective action up to and including insurrection and revolution. Movements here are '[abnormal]{style="color:red;"},' consequences and manifestations of strain, deprivation, and grievance.

- key concepts
    * [grievance]{style="color:darkred;"}
    * (relative) [deprivation]{style="color:darkred;"}

## Resource mobilisation theory

- origins: shift from 'why' collective action to '[how]{style="color:red;"}' collective action
- some key scholars: McCarthy & Zald, Tilly, Tarrow, McAdam

- focus on organisations: how they mobilise and campaign in [strategic]{style="color:red;"} pursuit of goals
- degree of resources under the [control]{style="color:red;"} of a movement 

- key concepts: 
    * [strategy]{style="color:darkred;"} and [tactics]{style="color:darkred;"}
    * types of resources: [material]{style="color:darkred;"} (finances, property, supplies), [human]{style="color:darkred;"} (quantity and expert quality of members/activists), [organisational]{style="color:darkred;"} (capacity to disseminate and enact strategy), [moral]{style="color:darkred;"} (solidarity support, legitimacy and sympathetic support)

## Political process theory (PPT)

- broadening from organisational focus to surrounding structure
- some key scholars: della Porta, Tilly, Koopmans, Rucht

- key concepts:
    + [opportunity structure]{style="color:darkred;"}
        * political [@Kitschelt1986]
        * discursive [@Koopmans2004]
    + [mobilising structures]{style="color:darkred;"}
    + [cycles of contention]{style="color:darkred;"} [@Tarrow2011]
    + [contentious repertoires]{style="color:darkred;"}

- common focus on 'protest event data'---means of comparatively measuring effects of political opportunities

## Summing up {auto-animate=true}

- Not exhaustive of SMS theories. There's also: *political mediation model*, *field theory*, *relational/network approaches*, etc.

## Summing up {auto-animate=true}

- PPT and concepts from the other main theories provide framework for research on the far right
- Not exhaustive of SMS theories. There's also: *political mediation model*, *field theory*, *relational/network approaches*, etc.

## Movement-parties concept

- organised, registered as *political party*
    + fielding candidates, contesting elections (even if just locally)

::: {.fragment .custom .blur}
- mobilises members and supporters in extra-institutional activism like *social movement*
    + protests, cultural events beyond purpose of supporting election

:::

::: {.fragment .custom .blur}
*combine electoral representation with extra-institutional mobilisation* [@kitschelt2006movement]

- treating as parties neglects distinctive [movement-style activism]{style="color:cadetblue;"}
- treating as movements neglects unique [instrumentalisation of institutional politics]{style="color:cadetblue;"}

:::

## Movement-parties - conceptual comparison {auto-animate=true}

| Feature   | Party                 | Movement                    | Movement-Party           |
| --------- | --------------------- | --------------------------- | ------------------------ |
| Goal      | Win elections, govern | Influence culture/policy    | Both                     |
| Structure | Bureaucratic, stable  | Fluid, network-based        | Hybrid                   |
| Strategy  | Policy platforms      | Protest, activism           | Mixed                    |
| Members   | Formal                | Informal, participation     | Flexible                 |

## Sardines [@ColomboETAL2021]

> RQ(s): how can support for FR be curbed? "we ask whether bottom-up mobilization against the far-right can undermine or boost support for the far-right. What happens when citizens mobilize in grassroots rallies against far-right political actors?" (p2)

. . . 

- cf. @lagios2022DoesItPay and @ellinas2023MovementPartyElectoral

. . . 

findings: grassroots mobilisation can decrease appeal of FR ... 

## Sardines [@ColomboETAL2021]

findings: grassroots mobilisation can decrease appeal of FR ... 

- possible mechanisms?

. . . 

(1) [social pressure effect]{style="color:cadetblue;"}, reinforcing stigmatisation of FR politics, 

. . . 

(2) [informative effect]{style="color:cadetblue;"}, raising awareness of FR threats, 

. . . 

(3) [outing of (voting) intent]{style="color:cadetblue;"}, committing demonstration participants/supporters to a certain electoral choice

. . . 

- But also possible *[backlash effects]{style="color:darkred;"}*
